text: Darkness. The faint background hum of a refrigerator. A l clicks on, briefly, then snaps off again. Then on again, for a little longer. We wake groggily with JACK (five), blinking up at MA (26) She's standing in a worn t-shirt and underwear beside a l switching it on and off at apparently random intervals. S cranes up at the recessed skylight, Room's only window. The irregular flashes of lamp-light reveal glimpses of th little world lined with cork: ten foot a side, seven foot high, gabled ceiling rising to ten foot. Clusters of Jack's and Ma's vivid drawings are pinned all over the walls, quivering in the draft from the vents. Do with five crayons (red, yellow, blue, orange, green) and pencil on toilet tissue, lined pages or cardboard, they s dogs, trees, aliens, rocket ships, figures labelled 'Jack 'Ma'. Delicate mobiles (uncooked spaghetti, threads, plastics, foil, down from pillows, cloth scraps) dangle. A wardrobe with slatted louver doors. On top, toys crafte from garbage, a Labyrinth from toilet-roll insides. A dresser with a TV. A homemade pack of cards, papier mГў checkers and chess. A Fort constructed from vitamin and o bottles and cans. A single meagre African violet in a pot the TV. A round dining table, two fold-up chairs side by side. A bath with a single small towel over the side. A toilet, with a flotilla of homemade toy boats floating the tank which is oddly missing a lid. A sink, with a single worn toothbrush, toothpaste, dish s a broken comb, folded rags for washcloths. A small square mirror tile hung up over it. A small kitchen cabinet. A dish rack: two each of big and small white plates, bowls, tumblers, knives, forks, spoon (one with a melted handle), a scissors, can opener, serra knife, wooden spoon, spatula. A basic stove (with more folded rags on its handle, for p holders), one frying pan and one saucepan. A small refrigerator (more toys on top), a tiny trash.

A rocker.    Above, a shelf. Ten books stacked. Homemade A reddish Persian-style rug on the floor. A grey steel door, no handle. On the wall, a ten-digit keypad with a red light like a watching eye. Ma looks over at Jack and sees that he's awake. She mouth 'Sh' at him, soothing him back to sleep. Keeps signalling Darkness again, as Jack's eyelids fall.
Faint light. Jack and Ma sleep face to face in a double b under a thin quilt. Pale skin, long hair, wearing t-shirt
You cried all day and left TV on till you were a zombie. But then I zoomed down from heaven through Skylight into Room - (makes noise of descent, then crash landing)
and I was kicking you from the inside, boom boom, and then I shot out onto Rug with my eyes wide open, and you cutted the cord and said "Hello Jack." Jack wakes.
Ma. I'm five!
A little later, Ma, at the kitchen counter, measures out small bowls of cereal. Jack moves round Room touching things: Rug's rusty bloods from his birth; the scarred Table; chairs; faucets, etc.
Morning lamp, Morning rug, Morning wardrobe .. (he looks under the bed)
JACK (CONT'D)
Morning Eggsnake. It's my birthday. I'm five.

Ma puts breakfast on the table. Sits. Jack sits, too. Ma gives him a half vitamin pill from an almost empty tub. She takes a contraceptive pill from a generic pack. They start to eat. Ma winces. JACK (CONT'D)
Is Bad Tooth hurting? MA (taps her head)
Mind over matter. He taps his head too as he chants the slogan. JACK
If we don't mind, it doesn't matter. MA
Guess what we're going to make later. JACK
What? MA
A cake. JACK
A birthday cake, like in TV? MA
But for real.
A little later, Ma is brushing Jack's teeth (with their single, frayed brush) zealously. He spits with vigor. A little later, Ma and Jack are looking a two small piles clothes. MA
Come on slow poke. JACK
You, pink soft, pink swirls. MA
You always pick that. But I guess it's your birthday.
She reaches for her clothes. JACK
Me, bear and jeans. MA
Good choice! A little later. Ma scrubs the floor with an old cloth dia while Jack watches TV. Both in t-shirt and jeans (Jack's worn-out knees), but shoeless. DORA THE EXPLORER
We couldn't have done it without you. Thanks for helping. Gracias. The salsa theme tune starts. MA
Off, please. JACK
Just one more planet. Ma stands up, doing a zombie impression. MA

Too much TV will turn us into zombies ... Anyway, it's time to mark how tall you are. This makes him switch the TV off fast and run to the door Ma marks his height with a tiny 5 in black pen on the cor Jack ducks and uses his fingers to measure the gap. Frown JACK
I'm not very taller after four. MA
Oh, that's pretty normal. JACK
Yeah? MA
Everything's hunky-dory. JACK
Okey-dokey. He touches the space between 3 (in red) and 4 (in black).
JACK (CONT'D)
That's where Red Pen died and we got Black Pen for Sunday Treat. Hey, what about cookies? MA
Sorry, I already asked for jeans for you for Sunday Treat. He swallows his disappointment. JACK
I'm going to grow and grow till I'm a giant. Look, Ma. Look how big my superpowers are already. He makes a tiny bicep. Ma musters enthusiasm at the prosp of him growing up. MA
You'll be as strong as Samson soon. JACK (holding up his long hair)
Huger every day.
Gigantic. JACK
Enormous. Hugeormous. MA
Good word sandwich. He starts leaping around the room, moving gracefully betw all the familiar obstacles. JACK
I'm going to be Jack the Giant Giant-Killer and burst out of Skylight into Space with my dog Lucky and boing boing boing between all the planets...
A little later, playing 'Track'. The rug is draped over t table on the bed. They run back and forward on a worn C, of them training hard, like athletes.

Later, the furniture is back in place. Jack picks Dylan t Digger from his stack, which includes Pop-Up Airport, My Book of Nursery Rhymes, The Runaway Bunny, Alice in Wonderland. (He ignores the adult books - The Da Vinci Co Twilight, The Guardian, Bittersweet Love, The Shack.) Ma can't hide her revulsion at Dylan the Digger again. MA
Come on, you can read Dylan yourself. JACK
I can read them all but I like when you do. Ma recites animatedly. Jack turns the board pages, not noticing that Ma's eyes are shut as she reads from memory MA
Heeeeeeeere's Dylan, the sturdy digger! / The loads he shovels get bigger and bigger. / Watch his long arm delve into the earth, / No excavator so loves to munch dirt.
Later, Jack blows the second of two small eggs, keeping t shell intact. Beating butter and sugar, Ma keeps up their Rhyme game. MA
Our friend Table... just isn't able. Jack pours the eggs into her bowl of butter and sugar. JACK
Our friend Spoon, sings to the moon. Ma beats the eggs in. MA
Our friend Knife runs for his life. She winces in pain, and shakes out her right wrist. Jack notices and takes over, beating the batter for her.
Later: Ma strings the shells onto the needle tongue of th Eggsnake, made of eggshells crayoned, given paper clothes foil crowns, colored wool for hair... Eggsnake is hundred of eggs long.
A little later. The birthday cake is small, brown, plain. Ma makes a 5 with thin white icing. MA
Abracadabra! JACK
Now the candles. Reading her face, his crumples. JACK (CONT'D)
You said a birthday cake for real. That means candles on fire. MA
Jack - JACK
You should ask for candles for Sunday Treat, not dumb jeans. MA
Sorry. I have to ask for stuff we really need that he can get easily. JACK
But Old Nick gets anything, by magic.
Try your cake, I bet it's delicioso. But Jack is sulking. She hugs him, quietly soothing him. JACK
Next week when I'm six you better ask for real candles. MA
Next year, you mean. Later: Half the cake is eaten.
Jack is kneeling at the bath. There's a bucket with dishe front of him. He's washing up as expertly as an adult.
Later. Steam makes Room mysterious. Jack lies on Ma in th bath, both with bubble moustaches. End of the Selkie stor
But one day the mermaid finds where the fisherman hid her comb.
Ha ha.
So she runs home to the sea. She lets her head and face sink under the water. Jack sits up on her, upset. Ma emerges and opens her eyes.   Realizes what's wrong.
Of course she takes her Baby Jack with her.
Does he drown?
No, he's half-merman. He can breathe air or water, whichever. Satisfied, Jack leans over to scoop up the pile of clothe
Laundry Time. With relish, he plunges them under the water.
Laundry is hung up to dry everywhere. Ma and Jack are in their sleep t-shirts and underwear. She sits breastfeedin him and telling him a story.
... and Edmond swims and swims to the island of Monte Cristo and digs up all the treasure, and ...
A little later Jack watches as Ma places blankets and a pillow on the floor of the wardrobe.
Can we have more birthday cake?
Tomorrow.
Just a bite.
We've brushed our teeth already.
One more story? She checks her watch nervously: getting close to nine.

Jack, it's late. Come on. Jack jumps in and snuggles down. Pictures of Dora and her monkey Boots are glued on the back wall; this is a tiny r within Room. Ma covers him up for the night. She begins to sing `The Big Rock Candy Mountain'.

A little later. Dim light comes through the slats. Jack l stroking the dangling clothes, the pictures glued to the wardrobe. He freezes at the sound of the beeps that mean outside door is about to open. He lies absolutely still, listening for Old Nick's entran He savors the scent of fresh air, but shivers: winter. Boom: now the door's shut again.
Hey.
Hey. Jack goes up on his elbow to squint through the slats but only sees a bit of the man's down jacket as he takes it o
Here's the jeans.
Thanks.
The grapes were way too much, so I got canned pears. Jack can see Ma as she puts groceries away.
Now OLD NICK moves into view too. Forties, solidly built, blue-collar: a ordinary monster.
What's that? A birthday cake? He cuts himself a piece and eats it in a few bites. Ma starts getting undressed.
Shoulda told me, I'd have brought him a present. Jack twitches at this thrilling possibility. Old Nick starts undressing too: like some dull marriage.
What's he now, four? Jack, in the wardrobe, is all agog for Ma to correct him.
(too low to be heard)
Five. Sounds of the adults getting into bed. The lamp clicking Then the familiar creaks of the bed. Jack doesn't know wh they mean but is troubled. He counts them under his breat
One, two, three, four...

There's Room, then Outer Space, then Heaven. Plant is real but not trees. Spiders are real and one time the mosquito that was sucking my blood. But squirrels and dogs are just TV, except Lucky my dog that might be some day. Mountains are too big to be real and the sea. In the dark of the wardrobe, Jack is still counting.
One twenty-eight, one twenty- nine...

TV persons are flat and made of colors with red mouths and clothes instead of skin but me and you are real. Old Nick I don't know if he's real, maybe half? Green beans are real and chocolate but not ice cream. The bedsprings are speeding up.
Three hundred six, seven, eight - A primal grunt from Old Nick. The creaking is done. Jack asleep at the bottom of the wardrobe. Old Nick goes over to the TV and switches on sports.

Shh. He turns down the volume. The sound of the sports broadca overlaps with the thud of the door closing. The wardrobe opens admitting the faint light of the L.E.D on the keypa We cut to a shot of Ma putting a sleeping Jack into the b As she starts to climb in beside we pull back and crane u
Next morning. Jack watches a nature programme on TV: time lapse photography of one glorious tree.
Ma is using a needle and thread to take in Jack's new, mu too-big jeans. Jack finds a trodden cigarette butt under corner of the rug. Old Nick must have brought it in on hi shoe. Jack studies it.
Fallen leaves decompose and return nutrients to the soil.
(to herself, referring to the jeans)
Cheap piece of ... Jack looks at the sad African violet on the bedside table
Why Plant doesn't make flowers anymore?
Maybe she's tired.
Jack, on the bed: he squirms, twists, bounces with intens boyish energy. Beside the bed now, he runs on the spot at maximum speed. the background we see Ma cooking.

Later the same day. Ma is napping. Jack is playing on the floor. Counting things. Tracing the patterns of rug with finger. What was that? He stares at the floor by the stove; glimp something. Jack tiptoes over, but the moving thing is gone. He looks furtively at Ma then takes out the cake. He crumbles some sets the plate on the floor. He squats and waits. A mouse puts its nose out, sniffs and takes a crumb. Something smashes into the stove: one of Ma's heavy books Jack cries out in shock and distress.
You made him gone! Ma starts to sweep up the crumbs.
He was an alive thing, he was real!
They'd steal our food. She crawls under the counter, finds the hole. Tears alumi foil from the roll. Scrunches it.
Mouse can have my food, I'm not hungry.
They'd bring in germs, bite us in the night.
Mouse is my friend and you splatted him dead.
No I didn't, he's hunky-dory. She stops blocking up the hole to hug Jack.
Are you just tricking me?
I swear, he's safe at home with his Ma in the backyard.
What backyard? Ma, realizing her slip, tidies up instead of answering.
Mouse lives in a yard in TV? Ma holds up the aluminum foil to distract him.
Hey, let's make a UFO with this. Jack brings out the other grudge he's been nursing.
Why you didn't tell Old Nick it was my birthday?
Because he's not our friend.
He said he'd brung me a present.
You shouldn't hear what he - You're meant to be asleep.
I never had a present.
He didn't mean it.
It might be Lucky my dog.
Jack. We can't have a dog. We don't have room - (sees him misunderstand)
- space, enough space - cooped up in here with the barking, the scratching...
Lucky won't scratch, he promises.
There is no Lucky!
Yeah there is.
He's just made-up, in your head, he's not real. Devastated, Jack bursts into tears. Ma sits down beside him and strokes him.

That evening. Jack sits in Ma's lap, watching a TALK-SHOW hostess interview a one-armed war veteran. Ma is threadin eggshells onto a string, hundreds of shells long. Jack ge supports the unraveled part. Ma lets out a big yawn and discreetly rubs her aching jaw
...most poignant aspect, I can speak for all our viewers, so, so deeply moved by what you endured.
Ma. Where are we when we're asleep?
Right here in Room.
But dreams. Do we go into TV for dreaming?
We're never anywhere but here.
I want some. They put down Eggsnake and Ma turns to him so he can breastfeed.
Ma lies on the bed. Jack is nowhere to be seen. Eventuall his voice comes from the wardrobe.
Ma! I think Old Nick lives in TV, like Mouse. That's where he goes when he's not here in Room.
Jack. Go to sleep.

The third morning. Jack wakes up in the bed, where Ma alw carries him once Old Nick has gone. Ma is up already, sitting at the table, staring at a shin red truck and remote in a hard pack. The snake is in Eden Jack can hardly believe what's in front of him. He looks it for a while.
You can open it. We watch as Jack opens the box. Ma tries to help him when finds the packaging difficult.
(pulling it away from her)

I can do it. Later, Jack is playing with his new toy. Ma watches him uneasily. We hear a faint echo of screaming ... CHAPTER TITLE: UNLYING The screaming get's louder. Later, Ma is standing on a chair screaming and howling at Skylight. Jack stands in the bath screaming into the smal air vent above the shelf. He holds his truck up to the ve so it can join in. Then they hush and listen.
Why the aliens never scream back?
I guess they still can't hear us.

Tomorrow we'll do even louderer. Later, Ma, preoccupied, trims mold off cheese she slices thin and lays on brown bread. Puts it in the toaster oven Jack zigzags his truck around chair and table legs. Ma ch to see if the frozen peas are boiling yet. Jack drives th truck at the door: clang.
Jack!
What smells bad? Ma belatedly realizes the grilled cheese is smoking. She burns her hand slightly on the oven, wrenching it ope
That evening. Jack, in the wardrobe, is meant to be aslee but he's still playing with his truck. The door beeps; he kneels up for a glimpse as it booms sh
Hey. What's the smell? He puts down groceries, unzips his jacket.
Sorry, I burned some cheese.
You need to take more care.
I will. I wasn't thinking.
Yeah, well, thinking's not your strong suit.
I know. I'm really sorry. Ma is unpacking the groceries.
So did he like his truck? He laughs at her speechless discomfort.
I know boys, I was one once. Ma looks at the empty bag.
The vitamins?
Waste of money.
If we had a better diet, maybe...

Here we go again. You know instead of complaining maybe you should thank your lucky stars you've got a place like this. Cosy, safe, specially with the kid - no drunk drivers, drug-pushers, perverts...
I'm sorry.
Like pulling teeth sometimes. Ma waits for him to calm down.
Your problem is you have no idea about the world of today.
No.
Who pays the power bills? Who pays for everything? She gives the required answer.
You.
And where do you think the money's going to keep coming from?
What do you mean?
Nothing.
No, but -
Six months I've been laid off, have you had to worry your little head? Pause as Ma takes in the implications of this. She procee cautiously.
What are you going to do? He doesn't answer.
Are you... looking for another job?
What job? There are no damn jobs, Jesus Christ! Jack, frightened, shrinks back in the wardrobe knocking i the back panel. Old Nick turns his attention to the wardr
Hey in there.
He's asleep.
Don't think so. You keep him in the closet all day as well as all night? Poor little freak has two heads or something? He roots in his jacket pockets and produces an already op tube of hard candy.
Hey Jack. You like candy? Wanna come out and have some candy? Jack, tempted, reaches for the door... Desperate to distract Old Nick, Ma touches his arm.
Let's go to bed. Old Nick chuckles at this unaccustomed seductiveness.
Now.
Didn't your Momma ever teach you manners?
Please.
Pocketing the candy, he wraps himself round her. They edge backwards out of view. The lamp snaps off.
A little later, everything is quiet.   Moonlight. Jack, asleep in a crooked position, wakes with a jump. He sits up and rubs his neck. Finds his truck. He opens the and peeks out. Where's the candy?
Stepping out, holding his truck for moral support, Jack stumbles into something and gasps. He picks it up: a thic leather belt, like a cobra.

He takes another few steps and stubs his toe on a huge bo Jack stares at Old Nick, asleep in the middle of the bed. Ma is sleeping too, clinging to the far side. Now he's come this far, Jack forgets the candy, fascinate Old Nick, whom he's seeing up close for the first time. Jack puts his finger out, almost touching Old Nick's face Old Nick's eyes open, startled.   Then he grins.
Hey sonny. Ma leaps up screaming and flailing at Old Nick.
Get away from him! Get away! Jack drops his truck and races to the wardrobe. He jumps in and pulls the door, banging his head.
Jack clutches his head, curled up in the corner of the wardrobe, because it hurts, and to shut out Ma's screechi
Stop that noise. Ma is suddenly muted. The thump of Old Nick throwing her on the bed. The lamp snaps on. Jack flinches and turns hi face away from the light.
Of all the crazy... Sound of him pulling his clothes on, kicking the truck aw
(hoarsely)
Just leave him alone. The door makes the three beeps.
Just don't forget where you got him.
Sound of the door opening, then shutting with a boom. Jac waits to hear what Ma will do or say to him. The lamp clicks off again: darkness. Jack dives out of th wardrobe.
Sorry I - sorry - sorry - He sobs and hyperventilates by the side of the bed.
Sorry I came out of Wardrobe. Ma takes him into bed with her.
It's OK. She soothes him.

Shot of ice-crystals on the skylight. Silence: no refrigerator hum. Jack wakes first, shivering, though he doesn't know why. is astonished by purple bruises around Ma's throat. As if feels his gaze, Ma wakes and musters a smile. Jack notice the white clouds of their breath in the air.

Ma, we're dragons. Ma sits up. Registers the chill. Getting out of bed, she turns on the lamp: no light. Jack is crushed to finds his Jeep, one wheel snapped off. Ma opens the refrigerator: dark inside. She's appalled.

He's cut the power. She glances at the keypad: its little red light is out. With a wild, illogical hope, she hurls herself at the doo and claws at its edges - but it's still locked. Jack watc bewildered: he's never seen her try to open it.
Jack is at the table reading to his injured truck from AL Both are dressed in all their clothes in an effort to kee warm.
For, you see, so many out-of-the- way things had happened lat-ely -
Lately.
- lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible. Ma comes to the table and doles out half-thawed green bea
Lunch!
No thanks.
We have to use them up before they rot. Once we eat we'll feel warmer. Jack makes himself chew a limp bean. Ma nibbles a few, wi show of enthusiasm. Jack looks at his three-wheeled truck
When's Old Nick going to put the power back?
Soon.
When's soon?
Once he's not mad with me anymore. Jack watches the bruises on her throat move.
I hope he never comes back not ever.
Jack.   Think about it. He does, with difficulty.
No Sunday Treat?
No anything. Jack tries the bean again - then spits it out quietly. Ma watches him, kisses him, forces herself to begin telling the truth.
Hey Jack. Remember the mouse?
My friend Mouse?
You know where he is right now? Jack looks all around Room.
On the other side of this wall. Jack stares hard at the wall.
What other side?
Oh Jack, everything has two sides.
Not an octagon.
No, that's -
An octagon has eight. Ma holds up her hand flat.
But a wall's like this. And we're on the inside, in Room, and Mouse is on the outside, see?
In Outer Space?
No, in the world.   It's much closer than Outer Space. She shows him the distance with her hands.
I don't see any outside side.
But if we were outside in the world, we would, we'd be looking at the other side of this wall, and Mouse lying in the grass with his Ma. We'd see trees and cars and -
Grass is just TV.
Is it, though? You know when Door opens and the air comes in, the air that smells fresher - that's grass. Jack tries to laugh.
You can't smell TV.
But it's not TV. It's the real world we smell. You're so smart, I know you've started wondering.
Jack shakes his head.
Where do you think Old Nick gets our food?
From TV by magic.
There's no magic! Everything we see on TV - it's pictures of real stuff and real people in the world.
Dora's real for real?
No, sorry, not Dora, she's just a picture, but the other ones, with faces like ours - and there's real streets and oceans, dogs, cats -
No way. Where would they all fit?
Just out there, in the world. Jack, tired of this, changes the subject.
Can I have a sandwich? Controlling her exasperation, Ma gets out a half slice of bread and adds a rationed scraping of peanut butter. She down his food and he comes to the table to eat it.
Ma stands with her hands in her armpits to warm them. She stares around as if for proof. Cranes up at the skylight.
Look! A leaf!
Where?
On skylight. She climbs up on a chair and lifts Jack onto her shoulder he can see. His head is close to the recessed skylight. H looks at a brown, sodden half-rotted leaf.
Dumbo Ma. That's not a leaf. Leaves are green.
On the trees they are but when they fall they rot, like salad, in the fridge, they -.
(interrupting)
Where's all the stuff you said? Trees and dogs and -
Well, we can't see them from here because the skylight looks upwards instead of sideways. Jack suddenly struggles to get down, nearly toppling them
You're just tricking me.
No I'm not.
Liar liar pants on fire!
Jack. I couldn't explain before, you were too small to understand, so.. I had to make up a story.

But now - it's the opposite of lying, I'm unlying, because now you're five I think you can understand about the world, you have to understand. Jack shakes his head, not in bewilderment but in resistan
Jack -
I want to be four again. They face each other, standing with the table between the Ma musters the energy to try again, telling him her own s this time. She picks up Jack's copy of ALICE IN WONDERLAN
You know how Alice wasn't always in Wonderland?
She fell down down down the hole.
Well, I'm like Alice. I wasn't always in Room. A heavy silence, as Jack absorbs this.
I used to be a little girl called Joy. I lived-
Nah!
I lived in a house out in the world (taps on the wall)
- with my mom and dad. You'd call them Grandma and Grandpa.
What house?
The house where we lived, with a hammock in the back yard. We used to swing in the hammock and eat ice cream.
A TV house?
It's not TV, Jack. Are you listening? No answer from him.
And then I was nearly grown up, I was seventeen, I was walking to school and -
Where was I?
Still up in heaven. So this guy ran up to me, saying his -
What guy?
We call him Old Nick, but I don't know his real name. He pretended his dog was sick, he seemed really -
What's the dog's name?
There was no dog. It was just a trick to get me into his truck. Old Nick stole me.
I want a different story.
You need to hear this one. He put me in his garden shed.
Where?
Here. Room's the shed. He's the only one with the code - secret numbers to open the door. I've been locked in here for seven years. Do you understand?
Jack's had enough.
This story's boring. Beat.
Jack, the world. You wouldn't believe how big it is. Room's only a tiny stinky piece of it.
Room's not stinky.   Only when you do a fart. Ma sit's down. She doesn't look at Jack.
I don't believe in your stinky world.
(bitter, still not looking at him)

Fine. That's fine Jack. Another long miserable pause. Jack, angry and upset, watc her for a while then sits down on the floor and takes out toys from under the TV. He plays quietly. Ma looks up at the skylight. As she watches a gust of win blow the leaf away. LATER - dusk Ma and Jack are in bed, under the duvet in their clothes, shuddering with cold. Jack tries the lamp. Nothing. He fi the dents in the shade then lies back down. A terrible flatness in the air. Ma is turned away from Jack. She has been crying.
Next morning, a sunny day. Jack wakes up beside Ma.
It's warm again. But she pulls the pillow over her head. He knows it's one of her rare catatonic Gone days.
Later. Jack eats cereal and watches DORA (sound on very l

Where do we go next? River, Bridge, Highest Hill. Will you check my backpack for something to help us? Later. TV off. Jack creeps up to Ma and studies what he c see of her bruises, which are more purple-black today. He tries to read Ma's watch but the angle makes it hard. He plays at switching Ma on with the remote. Later. Jack plays chess (with their homemade papier mГўch set) against his truck. Later. Kicks a shrivelled red balloon to keep it in the a Later. It's turned cloudy. Jack nibbles a bagel at the ta Later.   He makes a tour of his domain, his friends.

Eggsnake's our longest friend and fanciest. Meltedy Spoon's the best to eat with because he's more blobbier. Labyrinth is the twistiest and she hides things so I don't know where. Toilet's the best at disappearing poo. Lamp's the brightest except when the powercut. (glances at Ma)

You're the best at reading and songs and lots except if you're having a Gone Day. I'm the best at drawing and jumping and growing and nearly everything. He examines the truck's broken axle. Yanks on another whe until it snaps off. Then the last two. He twists the door off. Stuffs the truck, its parts and remote in the trash. Later, light fading. Jack lies beside Ma, longing to breastfeed. Lifts the edge of her t-shirt, but doesn't da He sits up, rests his hand on the bump of Ma's foot.
Next day. Ma (apparently normal again) and Jack finish th cereal.
Apple? He takes a big bite and hands it back to her. Ma bites in, winces. She reaches into her mouth and pulls a tooth.
About time.
Bad Tooth? Can I have it?
Sure, if you want it.

A little later. Jack is watching wildlife while Ma cleans from breakfast: baby turtles emerging from shells and hea down the beach. Tying up the trash bag, she finds the truck, and realizes that Jack has destroyed it because it came from Old Nick.
Are turtles real? Ma's head shoots up: this is the first sign that he's starting to believe her about the world.
Totally real. I had a pet turtle.
Crocodiles, sharks, and hungry fish are all waiting in the shallows.
Crocodiles and sharks -
They're all real.
Curious, Jack switches channels: a 1970 BBC mini-series, SIX WIVES OF HENRY VIII.
Oh, my lord...
(eyeing the child)
Not while he plays here...
(smiling)
I'll send him away -
Real?
Ah, they're real people playing dress-up, pretending to be people from hundreds of years ago. Jack is puzzled by that. He switches channels: TOM AND JERRY.
Just TV?
You're getting it! He watches the slapstick violence with relish.
When Old Nick comes back, I'm going to kick him in the butt. This suddenly punctures her mood.
Jack. Ma marches over and turns off the TV, startling him.
